title: When the Rules Matter More Than the Results
excerpt: Seb Coe discusses the impact of hosting the World XC in the USA and insights on improving athlete recognition.
body:
The news that Sebastian Coe has publicly acknowledged concerns about the World Athlete of the Year voting process, particularly around transparency and fairness, isn't just insider sports politics. It highlights a broader theme that all runners can relate to: Recognition should reflect true performance, not hidden criteria.

For everyday athletes this speaks to something depper: Runners train in plain sight, their times, efforts, and race history are open for all to see. But, accolades, rankings, and subjective awards often lack the same objectivity. When top sports officials publicly question how winners are chosen, it draws attention to a core value: fairness matters at every level of a sport.

This story isn't about rehashing the specifics of elite awards. It's about the lesson every runner can take home: Measure what can be measured. Advocate for clarity in how success is defined. And don't let opaque systems determine your self-worth or goals.

Whether you're aiming to run your first 5k or chase an Olympic standard, transparency in how achievements are evaluated, in awards, rankings, in your own training, makes the journey more meaningful.
keyTakeaway: External recognition is often imperfect. Your progress shouldn't depend on opaque systems. In running, what matters most is what can be measured and controlled: consistency, effort, improvement, and how you show up on race day.
